Refer to this link for build results (access rights to CI server needed): 
https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/1565/
Thanks @niketanpansare, tests passed, I shall merge.

Refer to this link for build results (access rights to CI server needed): 
https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/1566/

btw, there are apparently a number of failed tests - I would recommend to start with tests like GLMDMLTest which currently fail with index out of bounds exceptions. 

Subsequently, we need to look at a couple of tests where the new rewrite destroys sparsity exploiting operators (e.g., WeightedUnaryMatrixMultTest, where W*(2*(U%*%t(V))) is reordered to something like 2*(W*(U%*%t(V)))) which creates an unnecessary sparse intermediate, while otherwise we would compile a single fused operator. We might want to consider alternative orderings but let's get the list of problematic cases first (in some instances like the above, the test cases are rather artificial and would not affect real-world scenarios).

I added scalars to the test case. These sort as expected, though I did have the sort order reversed at first (it is so easy to get the wrong order on compare methods). Another rule splifies the scalars later.  The test is `2*X*3*Y*4*X` which rewrites to `Y*(X^2)*24`.

I also manually checked that vectors sort correctly. Unfortunately I couldn't figure out how to get R to element-wise multiply a matrix by a scalar, so I left this out. I also don't know how to check the output to see if the scalar rewriting (to 24) or vector re-ordering is successful, since these do not appear in the heavy hitter output.

Ah okay, I see the overlap. Sure, let's go with the existing method.

On Sun, Jun 11, 2017 at 12:43 AM, Matthias Boehm <notifications@github.com>
wrote:

> *@mboehm7* commented on this pull request.
> ------------------------------
>
> In src/main/java/org/apache/sysml/hops/rewrite/HopRewriteUtils.java
> <https://github.com/apache/systemml/pull/540#discussion_r121274464>:
>
> > @@ -241,7 +241,24 @@ public static void addChildReference( Hop parent, Hop child, int pos ){
>  		parent.getInput().add( pos, child );
>  		child.getParent().add( parent );
>  	}
> -	
> +
> +	/**
> +	 * Replace an old Hop with a replacement Hop.
> +	 * If the old Hop has no parents, then return the replacement.
> +	 * Otherwise rewire each of the Hop's parents into the replacement and return the replacement.
> +	 * @param old To be replaced
> +	 * @param replacement The replacement
> +	 * @return replacement
> +	 */
> +	public static Hop replaceHop(final Hop old, final Hop replacement) {
> +		final ArrayList<Hop> rootParents = old.getParent();
> +		if (rootParents.isEmpty())
>
> well, it's a nice to have comment but it's generally useful to use common
> primitives for all rewrites (which makes later refactoring much simpler).
> Maybe you can simply add this empty check to rewireAllParentChildReferences
> (which would also work for empty parents) in order to avoid the unnecessary
> ArrayList creation?
>
> —
> You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/apache/systemml/pull/540#discussion_r121274464>, or mute
> the thread
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/ABm-dkICYRT9D-X1jkaBIl4usG-R00Pdks5sC5q_gaJpZM4N2Dji>
> .
>
The tests should pass now. I had a visit status "hole in the middle" bug \~_\~, now fixed

Welp, I take that back. The test `ElementwiseAdditionMultiplicationTest.testTerm3` fails due to a numerical problem. This test computes `(A*B)*C`.  The rewrite re-orders this multiplication to `A*(B*C)`. Evidently this is enough of a difference to make the results not match. Look at these differences:

	(1,1) mismatch: expected 369.2084378683617, actual 369.2084378683618
	(3,3) mismatch: expected 656.166016794371, actual 656.1660167943709
	(2,3) mismatch: expected 42.394954799451014, actual 42.39495479945101
	(3,1) mismatch: expected 125.49664338031643, actual 125.49664338031641
	(1,2) mismatch: expected 222.4603650962903, actual 222.46036509629027
	(5,1) mismatch: expected 20.237240311264287, actual 20.237240311264284
	(1,4) mismatch: expected 183.04079237620041, actual 183.04079237620044
	(2,4) mismatch: expected 213.53422063724432, actual 213.53422063724435
	(5,3) mismatch: expected 31.27887759608941, actual 31.278877596089405
	(3,4) mismatch: expected 96.92834272428424, actual 96.92834272428425
	(5,2) mismatch: expected 61.48072685290718, actual 61.480726852907175

I say we change the test :)

We'll see if there are other problems, like the sparsity-order-exploiting case you mentioned.

great - good progress. 

1) Regarding the check for scalar rewriting, you could run in forced spark execution mode and check for the number of execute spark instructions (scalar operations will never result in distributed operations). 

2) So I hope you already used your extended hop dag validator to find it. ;-)

3) Yes, you can change the test to use a tolerance of 1e-10, which can be passed as epsilon into compareResults.

@niketanpansare This will require a change in Caffe2DML for the shape of the filters `W`, unless you are using the `init` function already.  We still are using `F` filters, but the shape of `W` is now `(C, F*Hf*Wf)`.

Thank you Niketan for reviewing!  I will merge.

I'm having trouble understanding the organization of the numbers within a filter. For the simple case of F=2, C=1, Hf=2, Wf=2 such that the first filter is
`1 2`
`3 4`
and the second filter is
`5 6`
`7 8`
what should W look like?

I just pushed a fix for a bug in the associated unit test, and in the process have uncovered an optimizer bug.  Essentially, for the [`conv2d_transpose` unit test](https://github.com/apache/systemml/pull/541/files#diff-69f1f9f08f0278c1419977edb4932fa1L112), the [`bias_add` function in `conv2d_transpose::forward`](https://github.com/apache/systemml/pull/541/files#diff-46627746109842440ab3f87b3e9b9197L85) is causing the number of rows in `out` to incorrectly increase from `2` to `3`.  If an `if (1==1) {}` cut is added just before the `bias_add` function, the issue does not occur.  Interestingly, the [gradient check for `conv2d_transpose`](https://github.com/dusenberrymw/systemml/blob/181585887fcf50ae7e9f7ec475a8596c63416916/scripts/nn/test/grad_check.dml#L620) does *not* have the same issue, despite also calling the same `conv2d_transpose::forward` function.

cc @mboehm7 Can you look into this?

cc @bertholdreinwald, @niketanpansare
@niketanpansare do you wanna look into this bug described above (as it's likely related to your ConvolutionOp) - just let me know
Sure, will look into it.

Refer to this link for build results (access rights to CI server needed): 
https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/1578/

@dusenberrymw You answered my question but I am not sure I fully understood the representation.

For the following example W in FCHW format with F=C=Hf=Wf=2:
`20 21 22 23 24 25 26 27`
`30 31 32 33 34 35 36 37`
Is this the corresponding CFHW representation?
`20 21 22 23 30 31 32 33`
`24 25 26 27 34 35 36 37`

If yes, then I think the above transformation can be achieved with a simple DML function. Do you think that would be useful?

Yeah `W` is a 4D tensor, and it is transformed from shape `(F, C, Hin, Win)` to `(C, F, Hin, Win)` by transposing the first two dimensions.

Here's some Python code for demonstration, using your example `W`.

1. Create `W` with shape `(F,C,Hin,Win)`:
```python
import numpy as np
F = C = Hin = Win = 2
w = np.array([20, 21, 22, 23, 24, 25, 26, 27, 30, 31, 32, 33, 34, 35, 36, 37])
w = w.reshape(F, C, Hin, Win)
print(w)
```
```
[[[[20 21]
   [22 23]]

  [[24 25]
   [26 27]]]


 [[[30 31]
   [32 33]]

  [[34 35]
   [36 37]]]]
```

2. Transpose to `(C, F, Hin, Win)`:
```python
w = w.transpose(1, 0, 2, 3)  # (F,C,Hin,Win) -> (C,F,Hin,Win)
print(w)
```
```
[[[[20 21]
   [22 23]]

  [[30 31]
   [32 33]]]


 [[[24 25]
   [26 27]]

  [[34 35]
   [36 37]]]]
```

3. Flatten to `(C, F*Hin*Win)` for SystemML:
```python
w = w.reshape(C, F*Hin*Win)
print(w)
```
```
[[20 21 22 23 30 31 32 33]
 [24 25 26 27 34 35 36 37]]
```

In general, having a DML `nn/util::transpose4d(dim1, dim2, dim3, dim4)` function would be useful for arbitrary dimension permutations of our (flattened) tensors, as is possible in NumPy.  If we had that function, then this layer could accept the normal filter tensor `W` of shape `(F, C*Hin*Win)` and then just transpose it to `(C, F*Hin*Win)` before usage.  For this layer, the drawback to using that would be having to perform the transposition during every `forward` & `backward` call.

TensorFlow follows the same approach of swapping the `F` & `C` dimensions for performance reasons (keep in mind that the spatial dimensions come first in TF).  [`conv2d`](https://www.tensorflow.org/api_docs/python/tf/nn/conv2d) uses a filter tensor of shape `(Hf, Wf, C, F)`, and [`conv2d_transpose`](https://www.tensorflow.org/api_docs/python/tf/nn/conv2d_transpose) use a filter tensor of shape `(Hf, Wf, F, C)`.

Refer to this link for build results (access rights to CI server needed): 
https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/1579/

I wouldn't want to transform W each time forward/backward is called either. The transformation should only be done once and then the transformed W should continue to be used.

If you're referring to a generic reshape that can perform arbitrary reshapes on 4D tensors, then I'm not sure if this can be achieved efficiently in DML (I think the corresponding builtin function would be very useful). A special reshape for FCHW -> CFHW is however, achievable in DML.

ok quick update on the "optimizer issue" - it has nothing to do with the compiler or runtime; the root cause is that CONV2D_BACKWARD_DATA messes up the dimensions during parsing, BIAS_ADD propagates these dims, the nrow is replaced and never reaches the compiler (which would actually correct these mistakes) - I'll deliver the fix soon.

please also think about how to handle the case where the driver memory budget is smaller than the GPU device memory.

Thank you for reviewing @gweidner!

@niketanpansare Well for this particular PR, `conv2d_depthwise.dml` is the regular "Convolution", but I'm working on the related one for conv2d transpose ("deconvolution").  For the `groups` attribute, it will be a depthwise conv when `groups` is equal to the number of **input** channels, i.e. the `num_output` from the **previous** layer.  Also, I would think that Caffe will have an upper bound on the number of groups as the minimum of either the number of input channels or the number of filters.  Otherwise, it wouldn't be possible to divide the number of input channels by the number of groups if there are more groups than input channels.  It would be worth checking on that.

@niketanpansare could you please review this PR and share you feedback.

Some commands
```
Help
./scripts/perftest/python/run_perftest.py --help
```

This command will run Kmeans on following modes

- datagen
- train
- predict 

and captures the metrics in the log file

```
To run Kmeans using defaults
./scripts/perftest/python/run_perftest.py --algo Kmeans
```

Another Variation. 
This will run Kmeans algorithm on various matrix dimensions defined in the `--mat-shape` argument
on all modes.

```
./scripts/perftest/python/run_perftest.py --algo Kmeans --mat-shape 10k_1k 20k_10 30k_50
```

If we just want to generate data for Kmeans

```
./scripts/perftest/python/run_perftest.py --family clustering --mat-shape 10k_1k 20k_10 30k_50 --mode  data-gen
```

PS: Please run all these scripts from root. ($SYSTEML_HOME). Right now this performance test suits supports single node execution with statistics and clustering. Please let me know if you have questions.

Thanks

Awesome work. LGTM for tasks completed until now :)

>> please also think about how to handle the case where the driver memory budget is smaller than the GPU device memory.

Good point. We need to have a separate discussion on how to handle this case optimally (for example: partitioned mb in CP). For 1.0, we could use `min(CP memory budget, GPU memory)`.

>> the memory estimates will not work if sparse inputs are converted to dense for any GPU operation or if the requirements for intermediate memory are different.

Sure, we can handle this in a separate PR.

LGTM. Thanks @nakul02  👍
@niketanpansare thank you for the review. :)

@deroneriksson: We are currently stuck due to some limitations in Flink that prevent us from reaching acceptable runtimes. Thus, I would suggest to close this PR in the meanwhile. Once we have reasonable support for caching and broadcast variables in Flink, we can think about the integration again.

What do you think?
